title: How to use the GeoStratR package
text: stratify can use function Stratify, automatically determines optimal number classes evaluating range possible groupings. function performs k-means clustering raster stack, testing minimum maximum number groups specified user. selects best number groups based chosen criterion. Stratify function allows choose two criteria selecting optimal number classes: Calinski-Harabasz Index (“calinski”): criterion measures variance clusters relative variance within clusters. higher Calinski-Harabasz index indicates better-defined distinct clustering structure, making suitable identifying well-separated groups. simple structure index (“ssi”): criterion assesses similar object cluster compared clusters. higher silhouette width indicates clustering cohesive objects appropriately assigned respective clusters. leveraging criteria, Stratify function ensures chosen number groups provides best balance within-cluster homogeneity -cluster separation. output includes raster layer pixel assigned optimal class, well dataframe summarizing performance tested grouping. enables users visualize analyze stratified areas effectively. ’s can use Stratify function Bios dataset determine optimal number classes visualize results:
code: result <- Stratify(Bios, LowGroup = 2, HighGroup = 10, Criterion = "calinski") #> Warning: Quick-TRANSfer stage steps exceeded maximum (= 178550)

text: determining optimal strata, can use function Random_Stratified_Min_Dist generate random stratified sampling scheme. function ensures sample points distributed minimum distance points within stratum stratum borders. specify minimum distance border, distance used spacing points applied border well. ’s example use function: resulting plot shows stratified sampling points overlaid optimal strata:  approach ensures balanced sampling: Random_Stratified_Min_Dist function robust can handle cases classes achieve desired number points. example: Even classes meet target 500 points, function still works effectively: flexibility ensures sampling scheme effective adaptable varying conditions within study area. maintaining minimum distances, function helps prevent clustering sample points ensures representative unbiased sampling distribution across strata.
code: Points <- Random_Stratified_Min_Dist(ClassRaster = result$FinalStack,                                      MinDist = 2000,                                      BorderDist = 5000,                                      n = 30,                                      n_to_test = 100) #> Joining with `by = join_by(x, y)` table(Points$Class) #>  #>  A  B  C  D  E  #> 30 30 30 30 30 Points2 <- Random_Stratified_Min_Dist(ClassRaster = result$FinalStack,                                      MinDist = 2000,                                      BorderDist = 10000,                                      n = 500,                                      n_to_test = 10000) #> Joining with `by = join_by(x, y)` table(Points2$Class) #>  #>   A   B   C   D   E  #> 500 500 500 462 335
